content.question: Show all your work for each part of the the question. The parts within the question may not have equal weight. Three segments of pipe are shown in Figure <math alttext="1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>1</mn></math>. The pipe is filled with water with density <math alttext="rho sub w" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><msub><mi>ρ</mi><mi>w</mi></msub></mstyle></math> that is flowing from left to right. The water moves with speed <math alttext="v sub 1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><msub><mi>v</mi><mtext>I</mtext></msub></mstyle></math> in Region <math alttext="1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi mathvariant="normal">I</mi></math>, which has a diameter <math alttext="2 d" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><mn>2</mn><mi>d</mi></mstyle></math>. The pipe narrows to diameter <math alttext="d" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>d</mi></math> before Region <math alttext="2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>II</mi></math>. The diameter of the pipe then remains constant through Region <math alttext="3" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>III</mi></math>. (a) The pressure in Region <math alttext="1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mtext>I</mtext></math> of the pipe is <math alttext="P sub 0" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><msub><mi>P</mi><mn>0</mn></msub></mstyle></math>.i. On the axis in Figure <math alttext="2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>2</mn></math> sketch a graph of the speed of the water in regions <math alttext="2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>II</mi></math> and <math alttext="3" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>III</mi></math>.

frqParts.text: Show all your work for each part of the the question. The parts within the question may not have equal weight. Three segments of pipe are shown in Figure <math alttext="1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>1</mn></math>. The pipe is filled with water with density <math alttext="rho sub w" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><msub><mi>ρ</mi><mi>w</mi></msub></mstyle></math> that is flowing from left to right. The water moves with speed <math alttext="v sub 1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><msub><mi>v</mi><mtext>I</mtext></msub></mstyle></math> in Region <math alttext="1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi mathvariant="normal">I</mi></math>, which has a diameter <math alttext="2 d" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><mn>2</mn><mi>d</mi></mstyle></math>. The pipe narrows to diameter <math alttext="d" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>d</mi></math> before Region <math alttext="2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>II</mi></math>. The diameter of the pipe then remains constant through Region <math alttext="3" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>III</mi></math>. (a) The pressure in Region <math alttext="1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mtext>I</mtext></math> of the pipe is <math alttext="P sub 0" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><msub><mi>P</mi><mn>0</mn></msub></mstyle></math>.i. On the axis in Figure <math alttext="2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>2</mn></math> sketch a graph of the speed of the water in regions <math alttext="2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>II</mi></math> and <math alttext="3" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>III</mi></math>.

ii. Starting with Bernoulli’s equation, derive an expression for the pressure in Region <math alttext="3" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>III</mi></math> of the pipe in terms of <math alttext="P sub 0" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><msub><mi>P</mi><mn>0</mn></msub></mstyle></math>, <math alttext="v sub 1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><msub><mi>v</mi><mtext>I</mtext></msub></mstyle></math>, <math alttext="rho sub w" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><msub><mi>ρ</mi><mi>w</mi></msub></mstyle></math>, and physical constants as appropriate. Begin your derivation by writing a fundamental physics principle or an equation from the reference booklet.

A similar set of three segments of pipe are shown in Figure <math alttext="3" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>3</mn></math>. The pipes are filled with water that is flowing from left to right. The water moves with speed <math alttext="v sub 1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>v</mi><mtext>I</mtext></msub></math> in Region <math alttext="1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mtext>I</mtext></math>, which has a diameter <math alttext="2 d" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>2</mn><mi>d</mi></math>. The pipe narrows to diameter <math alttext="d" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>d</mi></math> before Region <math alttext="2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mtext>II</mtext></math>. The diameter of the pipe then remains constant through Region <math alttext="3" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mtext>III</mtext></math>.(b) A student correctly claims that the pressure in Region <math alttext="3" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>III</mi></math> could be greater than, less than or equal to <math alttext="P sub 0" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><msub><mi>P</mi><mn>0</mn></msub></mstyle></math>. Justify why this is true.

skill.text: 1.C: Create qualitative sketches of graphs that represent features of a model or the behavior of a physical system.
